title: Varying Coefficient Meta-Analysis
text: Implements functions varying coefficient meta-analysis methods. methods assume effect size homogeneity. Subgroup effect size comparisons, general linear effect size contrasts, linear models effect sizes based varying coefficient methods can used describe effect size heterogeneity. Varying coefficient meta-analysis methods require unrealistic assumptions traditional fixed-effect random-effects meta-analysis methods.

text: population effect sizes identical across studies, weighted average estimate biased regardless number studies sample size study. actual confidence interval coverage probability can much smaller specified confidence level population effect sizes identical across studies. constant coefficient model used caution, varying coefficient methods package recommended alternatives. varying coefficient methods require effect-size homogeneity across selected studies. constant coefficient meta-analysis function included vcmeta package primarily classroom  demonstrations illustrate problematic characteristics constant coefficient meta-analysis model.

title: Confidence interval for an average effect size using a random coefficient model — meta.ave.gen.rc
text: random coefficient model assumes studies meta-analysis random sample definable superpopulation studies. assumption difficult justify. effect sizes correlated weights (common occurance), weighted average estimate biased regardless number studies sample size study. actual confidence interval coverage probability can much smaller specified confidence level effect sizes correlated weights. confidence interval tau-squared assumes true effect sizes superpopulation studies normal distribution. large number studies, large sample size, required assess superpopulation normality assumption accurately estimate tau-squared. confidence interval population tau-squared hypersensitive minor difficult--detect violations superpopulation normality assumption. random coefficient model used caution, varying coefficient methods package recommended alternatives. varying coefficient methods allows effect sizes differ across studies, require studies random sample definable superpopoulation studies. random coefficient function included vcmeta package primarily classroom demonstrations illustrate problimatic characteristics random coefficient meta-analysis model.

what: Confidence interval for an average point-biserial correlation — meta.ave.pbcor
title: Confidence interval for an average point-biserial correlation — meta.ave.pbcor
text: Computes estimate, standard error, confidence interval average point-biserial correlation two studies. Two types point-biserial correlations can meta-analyzed. One type uses unweighted variance appropriate 2-group experimental designs. type uses weighted variance appropriate 2-group nonexperimental designs simple random sampling (stratified random sampling) within study. function requires point-biserial correlations type.  Use meta.ave.cor.gen function meta-analyze combination biserial correlation types.

what: Forest plot for average effect sizes — meta.ave.plot
title: Forest plot for average effect sizes — meta.ave.plot
text: Generates forest plot visualize effect sizes estimates overall averages meta.ave functions vcmeta. column exp(Estimate) present, function plots exponentiated effect size CI found columns exp(Estimate), exp(LL), exp(UL). Otherwise, function plots effect size CI found columns Estimate, LL, UL.

title: Forest plot for average effect sizes — meta.ave.plot
code: meta.ave.plot(   result,   reference_line = NULL,   diamond_height = 0.2,   ggtheme = ggplot2::theme_classic() )

title: Forest plot for average effect sizes — meta.ave.plot
text: result result matrix replicate functions vcmeta reference_line Optional x-value reference line.  applies focus 'Difference' ''.  Defaults NULL, case reference line drawn. diamond_height Optional height diamond representing average effect size. applies focus 'Average' ''. Defaults 0.2 ggtheme optional ggplot2 theme object; defaults theme_classic()

title: Forest plot for average effect sizes — meta.ave.plot
text: Returns ggplot object.  stored, can customized via ggplot API

title: Forest plot for average effect sizes — meta.ave.plot
code: # Plot results from meta.ave.mean2 m1 <- c(7.4, 6.9) m2 <- c(6.3, 5.7) sd1 <- c(1.72, 1.53) sd2 <- c(2.35, 2.04) n1 <- c(40, 60) n2 <- c(40, 60) result <- meta.ave.mean2(.05, m1, m2, sd1, sd2, n1, n2, bystudy = TRUE) meta.ave.plot(result, reference_line = 0)    # Plot results from meta.ave.meanratio2 # Note that this plots the exponentiated effect size and CI m1 <- c(53, 60, 53, 57) m2 <- c(55, 62, 58, 61) sd1 <- c(4.1, 4.2, 4.5, 4.0) sd2 <- c(4.2, 4.7, 4.9, 4.8) cor <- c(.7, .7, .8, .85) n <- c(30, 50, 30, 70) result <- meta.ave.meanratio.ps(.05, m1, m2, sd1, sd2, cor, n, bystudy = TRUE) myplot <- meta.ave.plot(result, reference_line = 1) myplot   # Change x-scale to log2 library(ggplot2) #> Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 4.4.3 myplot <- myplot + scale_x_continuous(   trans = 'log2',    limits = c(0.75, 1.25),    name = "Estimated Ratio of Means, Log2 Scale" ) myplot

text: Returns ggplot object.  stored, can customized via ggplot API

title: Plot to compare estimates from original and follow-up studies — replicate.plot
code: # Compare Damisch et al., 2010 to Calin-Jageman & Caldwell 2014 # Damisch et al., 2010, Exp 1, German participants made 10 mini-golf putts. # Half were told they had a 'lucky' golf ball; half were not. # Found a large but uncertain improvement in shots made in the luck condition # Calin-Jageman & Caldwell, 2014, Exp 1, was a pre-registered replication with # input from Damisch, though with English-speaking participants. # # Here we compare the effect sizes, in original units, for the two studies. # Use the replicate.mean2 function because the design is a 2-group design.  library(ggplot2) damisch_v_calinjageman_raw <- replicate.mean2(   alpha = 0.05,   m11 = 6.42,   m12 = 4.75,   sd11 = 1.88,   sd12 = 2.15,   n11 = 14,   n12 = 14,   m21 = 4.73,   m22 = 4.62,   sd21 = 1.958,   sd22 = 2.12,   n21 = 66,   n22 = 58 )  # View the comparison: damisch_v_calinjageman_raw #>                       Estimate        SE         t          p          LL #> Original:                 1.67 0.7633058 2.1878519 0.03803154  0.09964253 #> Follow-up:                0.11 0.3682078 0.2987443 0.76566558 -0.61922358 #> Original - Follow-up:     1.56 0.8474743 1.8407638 0.07340024  0.13153488 #> Average:                  0.89 0.4237372 2.1003587 0.04232406  0.03245567 #>                              UL        df #> Original:             3.2403575  25.54543 #> Follow-up:            0.8392236 116.88772 #> Original - Follow-up: 2.9884651  38.36331 #> Average:              1.7475443  38.36331   # Now plot the comparison, focusing on the difference replicate.plot(damisch_v_calinjageman_raw, focus = "Difference")   # Plot the comparison, focusing on the average replicate.plot(damisch_v_calinjageman_raw,    focus = "Average",    reference_line = 0,   diamond_height = 0.1 )    # Plot the comparison with both difference and average. # In this case, store the plot for manipulation myplot <- replicate.plot(   damisch_v_calinjageman_raw,   focus = "Both",   reference_line = 0 )  # View the stored plot myplot   # Change x-labels and study labels myplot <- myplot + xlab("Difference in Putts Made, Lucky - Control") myplot <- myplot + scale_y_discrete(     labels = c(       "Average",       "Difference",       "Calin-Jageman & Caldwell, 2014",       "Damisch et al., 2010"       )   )    # View the updated plot myplot

vcmeta v1.5.0 (Release date: 2025/09/01)
text: Changes: New functions: se.propratio2, se.propratio.ps, se.agree, meta.ave.gen.log, replicate.agree, replicate.cronbach meta.ave.fisher function now deleted – use meta.ave.cor.gen se.semipartial renamed se.semipart, se.odds renamed se.oddsratio, meta.ave.odds renamed meta.ave.oddsratio, meta.lc.odds renamed meta.lc.oddsratio, meta.lm.odds renamed meta.lm.oddsratio se.prop2 se.prop.ps now use adjustment optimized number studies meta-analysis – note breaking change, parameter number studies must now passed.

title: vcmeta v1.4.0 (Release date: 2024/07/04)
text: CRAN release: 2024-07-04 Changes: New functions: se.bscor, meta.ave.cor.gen, replicate.cor.gen standard error standardized mean difference weighted variance standardizer meta.ave.stdmean2, meta.lc.stdmean2, meta.lm.stdmean2, se.stdmean2 functions longer assumes equal variances replicate.stdmean2 replicate.stdmean.ps functions now options additional standardizers – note breaking change, parameter standardizer must now passed.

title: vcmeta v1.3.0 (Release date: 2024/03/04)
text: CRAN release: 2024-03-04 Changes: New functions: se.cohen, replicate.ratio.prop2, replicate.prop.ps, table..odds, table..phi, meta.sub.gen ci.fisher function renamed meta.ave.fisher Corrected output error meta.ave.gen.rc function bystudy = FALSE cor..t now returns 1x1 matrix column ‘Estimate’

title: vcmeta v1.2.0 (Release date: 2023/06/26)
text: CRAN release: 2023-06-29 Changes: New functions: se.ave.mean2.dep, se.ave.cor., se.ave.cor.nonover, se.tetra, se.biphi, replicate.spear, replicate.mean1, replicate.prop1, stdmean2..t Corrected displayed standard errors replicate.cor

title: vcmeta v1.1.0 (Release date: 2022/06/30)
text: CRAN release: 2022-06-17 Changes: Updated documentation several functions New functions standard errors: se.prop2, se.prop.ps New function chi-square test homegeniety: meta.chitest New function confidence interval average variance: meta.ave.var New functions replication studies: replicate.prop2, replicate.oddsratio, replicate.slope meta.lm.cronbach now takes (alpha, n, rel, r, X) rather (alpha, n, rel, q, X) se.cor now takes (cor, s, n) rather (cor, q, n) meta.sub.cronbach now takes (alpha, n, rel, r, group) rather (alpha, n, rel, q, group) meta.ave.cronbach now takes (alpha, n, rel, r, bystudy) rather (alpha, n, rel, q, bystudy)

title: vcmeta 1.0.0 (Release date: 2021/08/21)
text: CRAN release: 2021-08-21 Changes: Added NEWS.md file track changes package.
